did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Baylor University, The Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society

did.abstract: The Poland Subject Files contain a variety of materials on multiple topics pertaining to government, state policy, martial law, oppression, violence, censorship, international relations, opposition movements, dissidents, religion, religious persecution, and publications.
did.langmaterial: English, French, German, Hungarian, Italian, Polish, Russian, and Ukrainian

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Keston College, originally founded in 1969 as the Center for the Study of Religion and Communism with the named changed to Keston College in 1974, collected and publicized details about religious persecution behind the Iron Curtain, becoming “the voice of the voiceless.” After the collapse of communism in the 1990s, Keston College moved to Oxford and downsized due to decreased funding. The name eventually changed to Keston Institute. In 2007, the Institute transferred the Keston Archive and Library to the newly created Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society at Baylor University.

Keston collected, verified, translated, and disseminated information received from believers in the Soviet Union, Poland, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and other communist countries. The Keston Archive and Library housed numerous letters, petitions, reports and underground publications (Samizdat) from believers of various denominations along with officially published books and periodicals.

Keston obtained materials from Poland starting in 1947. After the Yalta Conference, the Polish Provisional Government of National Unity was formed. Though there was Soviet domination in Poland at the time, many were unhappyDLsome believing that a third world war would defeat the Soviet Union. Elections were another source of unhappiness because of numerous claims of fraud due to Soviet Union control.

In the 1940’s following World War II, land was redistributed. The economy shifted from the wartime industrial basis to the Three-Year Plan of 1947 and the Six Year Plan of 1950. During this time, the government focused on employment and public education. As a result, adult illiteracy was almost eradicated and health care was easily accessible. Urbanization boomed and historic sites were rebuilt. Stalinization integrated propaganda into daily lives and public education.

After de-Stalinization in the Soviet Union in 1956, Edward Ochab became the First Secretary of the Polish United Workers’ Party and ushered in social reformation. His successor Wladyslaw Gomulka lessened dependence on the Soviet Union and formed ties with the Catholic Church in what became known as Polish October. Anti-Semitic factions within the Communist Party gained traction, and these ties created tension with remaining Polish Jews, most of whom were holocaust victims.

After the Marxist Revolution in 1965, the Conference of Polish Bishops wrote to German Bishops, and the two countries finally reconciled after the break following World War II. Protests mostly came in the form of art motivated by Prague Spring in Czechoslovakia. Academics, theatre, and education boomed.

After a series of price increases in the 1970s, workers revolted, and Edward Gierek replaced Wladyslaw Gomulka as First Secretary of the ruling Polish United Workers’ Party. Poland began borrowing from other nations and amassed considerable debt. Strikes and work stoppages were frequent until the Gdańsk Agreement of 1980. The authoritarian government of Poland declared martial law in December 1981, and imposed drastic restrictions until July 1983. Numerous labor leaders were imprisoned and some were killed. Eventually, the All-Poland Alliance of Trade Unions stabilized the trade organizations. Communism fell in Poland in 1989. Lech Wałęsa, who had served as chairperson of Solidarity and been imprisoned himself, became the first freely-elected president of Poland since the 1920s. In 1999, Poland became a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) along with the Czech Republic and Hungary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Poland Subject Files contain periodical clippings, reports, manuscripts, bibliographic references, and unofficial publications. They range from 1947 to 2002 with some undated. The bulk ranges from 1960 to 1989, with emphasis on government, state policy, martial law, oppression, violence, censorship, international relations, opposition movements, dissidents, religion, and publications. Notable topics include, but are not limited to, Pope John Paul II’s visits to Poland and the opposition movement Solidarity.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Keston Center received most of the Poland materials in files organized by specific categories and denominations. This original filing system has been largely preserved. Unprocessed materials which the Keston Center received in no particular order are arranged thematically and chronologically.
The Poland Subject Files are arranged in two series: I. General and II. Denominational

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to the Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Poland Subject Files, Box #, Folder #, Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Larisa Seago. Released on 2018-02-22.
Archivist''s Notes: The Keston Center is grateful to Eva Hruska, Chase Sonsalla, and Julia Pantleo for their assistance in preparing the Poland Subject Files finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes historical background, important individuals, governmental structure, martial law, oppressive practices, censorship, international relations, and opposition movements.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes information on the Roman Catholic Church, Judaism, and Anti-Semitism following World War II. The Roman Catholic files are the most extensive and contain information from general history of the church to detailed information on particular members of the clergy, including Pope John Paul II, Cardinal Josef Glemp, Fr. Stanislaw Malkowski, Fr. Jerzy Popieluszko, and others.
